Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First, identifying anomalies in the temporal profile. Lets look at each entry: 1. (R, A): 1 hour avg, 10 min STDEV. That seems reasonable, maybe typical. 2. (R, E): 1 day avg, 8 hours STDEV. Also plausible... 3. (R, P): 25 hours with STDEV 1 hour. Wait, thats a very tight window... 4. (A, C): 2 hours avg... 5. (E, N): 5 minutes... 6. (E, C): 1 hour avg... 7. (P, N): 7 days avg... 8. (N, C): 30 minutes avg.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So the main anomalies I can see are: - R to P with very low STDEV... - A to C being only 2 hours... - E to N in 5 minutes... - P to N taking 7 days on average.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Now, hypotheses for these anomalies. For R to P: Maybe the system automatically approves claims after a set time without proper evaluation... For A to C: Adjusters might be closing claims immediately after assignment... E to N in 5 minutes: Perhaps the notification is triggered automatically right after evaluation... P to N taking a week: Maybe after approval, theres a manual step...

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: But the process is supposed to go through E, P, N before C. If A to C is only 2 hours, maybe theyre closing without doing the intermediate steps? Thats an anomaly.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: To verify, calculate the actual average and STDEV from the data... Alternatively, look for claims where the time is within a narrow range... This might be complex. Alternatively, a self-join.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Wait, but need to pair each R with its subsequent P. Maybe better to use window functions... Hmm, this might be complex. Alternatively, for each claim, find the earliest R and the earliest P after that R.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Verification Queries: 1. Check R to P timing consistency: [SQL query] 2. Identify A followed directly by C without intermediate steps: [SQL query] 3. Analyze E to N timing: [SQL query] 4. Examine P to N variability: [SQL query] 5. Check for process order violations: [SQL query]
